On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the public prosecutor 's office summoned the applicant company and its manager , PERSON , to appear under the direct committal procedure at a hearing before ORG of the GPE tribunal de grande instance ( “ the GPE Criminal Court ” ) on DATE . They were accused of having , from DATE to DATE , acted as an intermediary between QUANTITY people , CARDINAL of whom provided services as a prostitute used or paid for by the other , by making available to those concerned a data - communications service CARDINAL ALINE which it provided with the [ aggravating ] circumstance that it was committed against several people .

On DATE the applicant company 's shareholders resolved at an ordinary general meeting convened on special notice to appoint Mr PERSON to represent it in the proceedings and to instruct a lawyer . Mr PERSON informed ORG of this in a letter of DATE .

At the hearing on DATE counsel for the applicant company informed ORG that , pursuant to LAW of LAW , the company had appointed PERSON to represent it and had duly informed the court . He submitted that the appointment of a representative ad litem to represent the company was “ superfluous ” and invited the court to accept Mr PERSON as the sole representative . Noting that the representative ad litem 's appointment under LAW of LAW was “ prior in time and valid ” , ORG found that the company was lawfully represented by PERSON and that it was PERSON PERSON 's appointment that was superfluous .
The applicant company was represented in court by a lawyer chosen by PERSON .

In a judgment of DATE ORG found Mr ORG and the applicant company guilty of the following offences : “ living on immoral earnings : acting as an intermediary between a person engaged in prostitution and the person employing him or her ” and “ living on immoral earnings aggravated by the fact that the offence was committed against several people ” . It imposed a fine of MONEY ( ORG ) on PERSON and ORG CARDINAL on the applicant company and ordered them jointly to pay damages of ORG CARDINAL to an association that had joined the proceedings as a civil party . The investigation and in particular the photographs of the connection to the ORG server CARDINAL - CARDINAL ALINE and the pages that followed show that , although it is stated that ' pseudos and CVs that are accessible to all users are constantly monitored and those containing a telephone number or messages relating to pornography , prostitution or the incitement of minors to immorality or illegal practices will be immediately disconnected ' , prostitutes are nevertheless put directly in touch with anyone wishing to reply to the messages .

Persons wishing to offer their services as prostitutes use a pseudonym , post a CV on the CARDINAL - CARDINAL ALINE network , open a data - communications mail account in which they receive messages to which they respond with a rate and telephone number and arrange meetings with interested clients .
Evidence of this modus operandi exists in the form of photographs taken by police officers .
Further , a review of previous cases handled by ORG has revealed that both male and female prostitutes have said that they used the CARDINAL ALINE server to offer their services as prostitutes .
In sum , there is ample proof that the CARDINAL - CARDINAL ALINE server was used in connection with prostitution .

At the hearing FAC did not dispute that he was responsible for monitoring the messaging service to ensure the proper functioning of the service ; he said that he supervised the teams of monitors and the pseudos registered on the server and had no hesitation in disconnecting non - compliant CVs . He said in the course of the investigation that he was no fool and was aware that many of the exchanges that took place on QUANTITY involved men and women offering services as prostitutes .
The defendants point to precautionary measures that had been taken , essentially monitoring , as evidence of their good faith and of the lack of mens rea to commit the offence charged .

However , that argument does not stand up to examination when the facts uncovered by the investigation are considered . No warning was issued or account disconnected in response to the simultaneous posting of numerous and , for the most part , wholly unambiguous pseudos , to the detailed CVs indicating measurements and the services on offer , or to the replies to messages setting out rates and telephone numbers .
On the contrary , these facilities enabled clients to find and speak to prostitutes , who in this instance were women .

The second argument advanced by the defendants is that it was impossible for them to intervene directly in the private sphere , the online discussions , without infringing the right to freedom to communicate in private .

... Eurofinacom PERSON , the service provider , undertook to ensure constant monitoring of the service in accordance with LAW and LAW [ of its ] agreement . Appendix CARDINAL contains a reminder of the main legislative provisions applicable to data communications including those concerning living on immoral earnings .

The interactive data - communications service CARDINAL - CARDINAL ALINE is governed by PERSON no . DATE of DATE , section CARDINAL of which requires prior notice to be given to ORG of an intention to provide audiovisual - communication services .
The circular issued on CARDINAL DATE pursuant to the said section CARDINAL adopts the definition of the notion of audiovisual - communication service .

Thus , audiovisual communication means a message intended for either the public generally or sections of the public , that is to say a group of undifferentiated people whose membership does not depend on considerations based on personal attributes .
Private correspondence means a message solely intended for CARDINAL or more specific , identifiable individuals or legal entities .

The court notes that in the present case prostitutes use the CARDINAL - CARDINAL ALINE service to make non - exclusive offers open to anyone wishing to respond who is then given a rate which is uniform at this stage of the exchange .
The exchange or discussion on the server does not acquire the character of private correspondence , owing to the fact that the advertisements and rates are available to all users of the service .
On the other hand , the finalisation of the agreement leads to a private telephone conversation between specific individuals which is covered by the rules of confidentiality .
In these circumstances , it is established that FAC and Eurofinacom PERSON allowed advertisements to be published without any proper supervision .
A prostitution service involving a number of people developed through the intermediary of the CARDINAL ALINE service .
It follows that all the constituent elements of the offence of living on immoral earnings with aggravating circumstances are present and that the charges against the defendants have been made out .

Following a request dated DATE by the person the applicant company had named as its representative , the President of ORG directed on DATE that PERSON appointment under the order of DATE would cease , as “ Eurofinacom is now duly represented in the criminal proceedings by PERSON PERSON ” .
The judgment of DATE was upheld in its entirety by ORG in a judgment of DATE . The applicant company was represented in ORG by a lawyer instructed by Mr PERSON .

ORG dismissed an initial objection by the applicant company that the proceedings were a nullity owing to Mr PERSON 's exclusion from the proceedings in ORG . ORG found that , since ORG had duly heard the submissions and arguments of counsel chosen by the judicial administrator , the applicant company had been properly represented and had had a fair trial at first instance . An objection by PERSON that the interception of private communications by the investigators was null and void was dismissed on the grounds that it had not been raised at first instance and could not be raised for the first time on appeal . On the merits , ORG held , inter alia :

Mr PERSON 's and ORG 's guilt ... is established by the fact that the relevant messages related to prostitution ... and by the evidence of several female prostitutes who confirmed that they frequently used the ' CARDINAL ALINE ' server , as it was a well - known and habitual part of the prostitution network . They even said that it enabled them to avoid soliciting on the street and to select clients more easily .

Mr PERSON 's affirmation that a team working TIME a day and DATE a week was assigned to monitor messages in order to eliminate those which were contra bonos mores is not accepted . Such affirmations are in total contradiction with the results of the investigation .

Inquiries made by the police services who accessed the server on DATE , and CARDINAL , DATE and DATE confirmed that none of the large number of prostitution - related messages were removed . Similarly , none of the prostitutes who used the server said in evidence that they had been ' disconnected ' after posting their advertisements and some ... even categorically stated that they had not been . Accordingly , Mr ORG has not established good faith on this point .

Likewise , it is not possible to accept Mr ORG 's argument that he was prevented from directly intervening in online discussions because they were private communications . Referring to the impugned judgment , ORG finds , like the court below , that the ' DATE ALINE ' server did not constitute a messaging service intended for CARDINAL or more specific , identifiable persons but a means of audiovisual communication offered to a non - specific and unidentifiable public . The server was accordingly governed by LAW , and in particular the provisions relating to the dignity of the human being and the preservation of law and order .

In particular , it was established that the police accessed the server by following the standard procedure available to the public at large and that the connection ended when the CARDINAL correspondents decided to transform the non - specific audiovisual communication into a personalised exchange on a private telephone line . Accordingly , despite the defendant 's denials , it is established that Mr PERSON knowingly supported an extensive prostitution network from which he made considerable profit .

There is also no doubt that there was a community of interest between Mr ORG , ORG 's manager , and the company he ran , as the investigation revealed that ORG 's activity was in fact the alleged criminal activity and that it achieved an estimated turnover DATE of MONEY .

The applicant company and Mr PERSON appealed to ORG . They submitted , firstly , that there had been a violation of LAW in that the trial court had ruled that the applicant company was represented in the proceedings by the representative ad litem appointed by the President of ORG instead of the person it had appointed to that end . Relying , inter alia , on the same provision , they argued , secondly , that the alleged offence had been “ the result of provocation and subterfuge ” . Thirdly , they submitted that the offence of living on immoral earnings with aggravating circumstances had not , in the absence of a positive act , been made out in law , as a failure to act or acquiescence did not suffice .
ORG ) dismissed the appeal in a judgment of DATE . With regard to the first ground of appeal , it held :

In dismissing ORG 's application to set aside the proceedings at first instance on the grounds that it should not have been represented by PERSON , ORG noted that Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure had been complied with and that the lawyer chosen by the company 's representative had been able to present his observations and arguments at the hearing .

In so doing , ORG , which found that the company had been properly represented and assisted in ORG , applied the law correctly , notwithstanding the superfluous reasoning criticised in the second limb of the ground of appeal .

The first subparagraph of Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure provides that when criminal proceedings are brought against a legal entity and its de jure representative is also prosecuted for the same or a related offence , a representative ad litem must be appointed to represent the legal entity in the criminal proceedings in accordance with the final subparagraph of that Article .
The second ground of appeal was dismissed for the following reasons :

“ According to the judgment of ORG and the judgment of the court below which it upheld , the investigation essentially took the form of questions to persons engaged in prostitution who used the ORG server to find clients and the retrieval by the police officers themselves of information from the data communications network .

ORG declared ORG objection that evidence obtained by the police through the interception of data communications should be excluded under ORG CARDINAL et seq . of LAW on the grounds that that provision had not been pleaded in ORG .
In so doing , ORG correctly applied the final subparagraph of LAW of LAW .

Lastly , ORG dismissed the third ground of appeal , holding that that it merely contestedthat had been the subject of adversarial argument , all of which were within the unfettered discretion of the courts below .

Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW lays down that legal entities may be held criminally liable for offences committed on their behalf by their organs or representatives . Such a finding will not preclude criminal liability on the part of individuals who commit the offence or act as accomplices .
As regards the representation of a legal entity that is a defendant in criminal proceedings , Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure provides :

“ The criminal proceedings shall be instituted against the legal entity acting through its de jure representative at the time the prosecution was brought . The de jure representative shall represent the legal entity at all stages of the proceedings . However , when criminal proceedings are brought against the de jure representative for the same or related offences , he or she may make an application to the president of the tribunal de grande instance for the appointment of a representative ad litem to represent the legal entity .
The legal entity may also be represented by any person who , in accordance with law or the memorandum and articles of association , holds a delegated power to that end .

A person who has been assigned the task of representing the legal entity under the second subparagraph shall inform the court before which the proceedings are pending of his or her identity by registered letter with recorded delivery .
The same rule shall also apply if there is a change of de jure representative while the proceedings are pending .

If there is no one qualified to represent the legal entity in accordance with the conditions set out in this LAW , the president of the tribunal de grande instance shall , on an application by the public prosecutor 's office , the investigating judge or the civil party , appoint a representative ad litem to represent it . ”

In a judgment of DATE ( Bulletin criminel no . CARDINAL ) , ORG held : “ By virtue of the first subparagraph of Article CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , if criminal proceedings have been instituted against a legal entity and its de jure representative or the person to whom power has been delegated under subparagraph CARDINAL of the aforementioned provision has also been prosecuted for the same or related offences , a representative ad litem must be appointed to represent the legal entity in the criminal proceedings , in accordance with the procedure set out in the final subparagraph ” .
Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides :
“ Living on immoral earnings shall mean using any means whatsoever :
CARDINAL To aid or assist another to engage in prostitution or to protect a person so engaged ;
CARDINAL To profit from or share the proceeds of another 's engagement in prostitution , or to receive an allowance from a person who habitually engages in prostitution ;
CARDINAL To recruit or procure a person for prostitution , to lead a person into prostitution or to exert pressure to make a person engage in prostitution or continue to do so .
Anyone living on immoral earnings shall be liable to DATE imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL . ”

Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL , subparagraph CARDINAL , of LAW lays down that “ anyone who by any means whatsoever ... acts as an intermediary between CARDINAL persons , one of whom engages in prostitution and the other of whom uses or pays for his or her services ” shall be assimilated to a person living on immoral earnings and liable to the penalties laid down by Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL .

Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL , subparagraph CARDINAL , of LAW adds that the maximum sentence shall be DATE imprisonment and a fine of MONEY for anyone living on the immoral earnings where the offence is committed against several people . Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ( published in ORG of DATE ) inserted a tenth subparagraph which provides that the same maximum sentence shall apply when the offence of living on immoral earnings has been committed “ with the help of a telecommunications network to disseminate messages to a non - specific public ” .
